item.title: Los mejores deportes para la longevidad
item.description: Todas las formas de ejercicio ayudan a vivir más tiempo, pero algunas actividades traen beneficios adicionales.
item.dc:creator: Simar Bajaj

item.title: Qué significa panacea
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 121 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Word of the Day: panacea
item.description: This word has appeared in 121 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Iran’s Regime Is Losing Its Greatest Weapon: Fear
item.description: The bulwark of Iranian oppression is fear. The latest round of demonstrations shows it has been breached.
item.dc:creator: Abbas Milani
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: via Getty Images

item.title: Fear of Venezuelan Oil Loss Is Stalking Cubans
item.description: The electricity may go off, but islanders see a glimmer of hope in Maduro’s departure.
item.dc:creator: Yoani Sánchez

media:content.media:credit: Norlys Perez/Reuters

item.title: Emergency Call Transcripts Record a Crisis Unfolding in Real Time
item.description: The killing of Renee Good by an ICE agent was instantly reported to the Minneapolis Police. The calls reflect shock, fury and confusion.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: After the shooting, a caller pleaded: “Send an ambulance please. Ambulance, please.”

item.title: Quote of the Day: In Bitter Winter Freeze, Russia Focuses on Wiping Out the Heat
item.description: Quotation for the Day for Friday, January 16, 2026.

item.title: Battles Over Truth Rage Online Amid Iran’s Internet Blackout
item.description: The shutdown of online discourse within Iran has allowed both the government and its critics to flood social media outside the country with disinformation campaigns and fake images.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers, Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson

media:content.media:credit: via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A frame grab from footage circulating on social media showing protesters dancing and cheering in Tehran last week.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 16, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 16, 2026.

item.title: They Ran a Campaign Together, Then Love Came After
item.description: When Talia Marcus and Charles Blaettler met while working on the campaign trail, they weren’t expecting love. Good thing it came anyway.
item.dc:creator: Stella Raine Chu

item.title: Please Cheat on Me
item.description: Why did I keep fantasizing about catching my faithful boyfriend in bed with another woman?
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sontag

media:content.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Uber’s Quest to Crack Japan Leads Through a Rural Hot-Springs Town
item.description: The ride-hailing giant’s chief executive has made a bet on how it can finally grab a bigger piece of one of the world’s largest taxi markets.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

item.title: A Slow, Awkward Dance Started It All
item.description: Before Paul Melnikow and Alan Pierson spoke to each other, they danced at the ‘queer prom,’ about 20 hours into Taylor Mac’s 24-hour performance.
item.dc:creator: Rosalie R. Radomsky

item.title: For Two Floridians, a Michigan Winter Solidified Their Bond
item.description: Ashley Knott and Tobias Kammerer are opposites — she’s very social, while he needs “to be peeled like an onion.” But a big move created a deeper connection.
item.dc:creator: Linda Marx

item.title: U.S. Says It Erred in Deporting Student Traveling for Thanksgiving
item.description: The Trump administration acknowledged it mistakenly deported a college student to Honduras despite a court order barring the removal. But the government has not moved to drop the case.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella

media:content.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's lawyer, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Any Lucía López Belloza’s high school graduation in Texas. She was detained and later deported in late November while trying to surprise her family with a visit.

item.title: Video Analysis of ICE Shooting Sheds Light on Contested Moments
item.description: Newly available videos and existing footage synchronized and assessed by The Times provides a millisecond by millisecond look at how an ICE officer ended up shooting and killing a motorist in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Video Analysis of ICE Shooting Sheds Light on Contested Moments
item.description: Newly available videos and existing footage synchronized and assessed by The Times provides a millisecond-by-millisecond look at how an ICE officer ended up shooting and killing a motorist in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Robin Stein, Devon Lum, Dmitriy Khavin, Alexander Cardia, Aric Toler and Jeff Bernier

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 2 Recap: Dirty Work
item.description: Viewers got extra intimate this week with the hard physical realities of life in the emergency ward.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins

media:content.media:credit: Warrick Page/HBO Max
media:content.media:description: Mel (Taylor Dearden, left, with Jesse Lambright) didn’t seem to realize she was being hit on, but it’s probably just as well.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 16, 2025
item.description: Kyle Dolan opens our solving weekend.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Machado Offers Trump Her Nobel Peace Prize Medal
item.description: During a meeting in the White House on Thursday, Venezuela’s opposition leader, María Corina Machado, presented her medal to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Venezuelan opposition politician María Corina Machado outside the U.S. Capitol in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Un nuevo videojuego simula un centro de ciberestafas
item.description: El juego “Blood Money: Lethal Eden” aprovecha una creciente ansiedad en China al recrear las experiencias de personas traficadas para dedicarse a la estafa.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado and Pei-Lin Wu

item.title: Many Fiery Remarks, Little Clarity on What’s Next at Security Council Meeting on Iran
item.description: Iran’s representative denied the country had killed protesters, as the U.S. ambassador said President Trump had made clear “all options are on the table” to stop the killing.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ahmad Batebi, right, a human-rights activist, delivered remarks at the United Nations Security Council meeting on Iran on Thursday.

item.title: This Winter, the Best Puffer Jackets Come With Big Pockets
item.description: These utility-inflected styles are practical yet polished.
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Bloomfield

item.title: Trump Administration Lawsuit Seeking California Voter Data Is Dismissed
item.description: The Justice Department has sued about two dozen states over access to voter rolls, as the federal government pushes to create a national database.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Rylee Kirk
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People

media:content.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Voting in Los Angeles last year. A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that the Justice Department had filed against California last year demanding access to voter data.

item.title: Venezuela’s Interim Leader Delivers State of the Union Address
item.description: In her State of the Union address, Delcy Rodríguez echoed her predecessors’ fiery rhetoric but tried to hew to President Trump’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Patricia Sulbarán

media:content.media:credit: Ariana Cubillos/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Venezuela’s interim president, Delcy Rodríguez, delivering a speech at the National Assembly in Caracas on Thursday.

item.title: Former Senator Kyrsten Sinema Accused of Affair With Member of Security Team
item.description: In a lawsuit, the ex-wife of Ms. Sinema’s onetime staff member accused her of showering him with gifts and breaking up their marriage.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Former Senator Kyrsten Sinema at the Capitol last month.

item.title: La medalla del Nobel se ha vendido antes por millones de dólares
item.description: El Comité del Nobel ha dicho que el premio no puede transferirse, pero la medalla se ha vendido en algunas subastas a lo largo de la historia del premio.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Desde la década de 1980, la medalla del Nobel se fabrica con oro reciclado.

item.title: California’s Pacific Coast Highway Fully Reopens After Three Years
item.description: The famed highway reopened this week after consecutive landslides shuttered two sections of the road in Big Sur and forced major repairs.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka

media:content.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

item.title: Taiwan Strikes Trade Deal with Trump, Vows More U.S. Chip Factories
item.description: The United States agreed to lower tariffs on Taiwanese goods from 20 to 15 percent, while Taiwan says it will invest in more chip manufacturing in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin, Amy Chang Chien and Xinyun Wu

media:content.media:credit: Wen-Yee Lee/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Taiwan manufactures most of the world’s advanced semiconductors.

item.title: Couple Says ICE Agents Gassed Them as They Drove With 6 Children
item.description: Shawn and Destiny Jackson said they were trying to escape a clash between ICE and protesters when agents used tear gas near their car. Their children gasped for air.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents, like these outside a federal building on Thursday, have frequently used tear gas on Minneapolis streets.

item.title: Former Building Super Is Convicted of Stealing $350,000 From 98-Year-Old
item.description: Rosalind Hernandez, who worked in a co-op building in Manhattan, befriended and then bilked a vulnerable resident, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko

media:content.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rosalind Hernandez was convicted of two counts of larceny in the theft of money from a resident of the co-op where she worked.

item.title: What Did the White House and Denmark Agree to on Greenland? Depends Whom You Ask.
item.description: The White House and Denmark contradicted each other in public about what they had agreed to this week as President Trump continued to demand U.S. ownership of Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Jeffrey Gettleman and Edward Wong

media:content.media:credit: Marko Djurica/Reuters
media:content.media:description: A Danish military vessel sailing near the old harbor of Nuuk, Greenland’s capital, on Wednesday.

item.title: The Nobel Peace Prize Medal Has Been Sold Before for Millions
item.description: The Nobel Committee has said the prize cannot be transferred, but it has been sold in a few auctions over the award’s history.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Since the 1980s, the Nobel medal has been made with recycled gold.

item.title: ‘The Rip’ Review: Clean Cop, Dirty Cop
item.description: Matt Damon and Ben Affleck play grizzled cops looking at each other sideways in this Netflix crime thriller that has all the concepts but not much else.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: Why ASAP Rocky’s New Album Took So Long
item.description: The musician and actor A$AP Rocky sat down with Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, the hosts of “Popcast” at The New York Times, to discuss the release of his first album in eight years.

item.title: Was Renee Good Obligated to Comply With an ICE Agent’s Orders?
item.description: The agent told Ms. Good to get out of her car before she was fatally shot. Legal experts said immigration agents may sometimes, but not always, have the authority to make such commands.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial for Renee Good. She was shot after beginning to drive away from an ICE agent who told her to get out of her car.

item.title: Humanities Endowment Awarding Millions to Western Civilization Programs
item.description: The National Endowment for the Humanities is giving more than $40 million to programs that have been embraced by conservatives as a counterweight to liberal-dominated academia.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler

media:content.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The University of Texas received $10 million to hire faculty members and help “launch academic majors in Strategy and Statecraft and Great Books.”

item.title: Democratic Lawmakers Say They Face New Round of Federal Inquiries
item.description: By Wednesday, at least five Democratic lawmakers said they received new inquiries from federal prosecutors regarding a video they published in November. In the video, they urged military service members not to follow illegal orders.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal and Daniel Fetherston

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Jason Crow of Colorado, one of the lawmakers being investigated, said President Trump was “using his political cronies in the Department of Justice to continue to threaten and intimidate us.”

item.title: Number of Businesses in New York City Plunged Last Spring, Report Says
item.description: Roughly 8,400 businesses closed in the second quarter of 2025, according to the most recent city data, creating the largest net decline in business activity since before the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag

media:content.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An empty storefront in Lower Manhattan. The drop-off in New York City business activity was most pronounced in major commercial districts, according to the Economic Development Corporation.

item.title: Las fuerzas estadounidenses incautan un sexto buque petrolero vinculado a Venezuela
item.description: La Guardia Costera de EE. UU. abordó e incautó el petrolero de bandera rusa, previamente llamado Veronica, en una operación realizada antes del amanecer en el Caribe.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Nicholas Nehamas and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Comando Sur de Estados Unidos, vía Reuters
media:content.media:description: Imagen de video difundida por el ejército estadounidense que muestra al petrolero Galileo, anteriormente llamado Verónica, en el Caribe el jueves.

item.title: Judge Proposes Restricting Deportation of Student Activists
item.description: In a case over the First Amendment rights of noncitizen scholars, a federal judge proposed extending protections to members of two academic groups behind a lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Scott Heins for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil speaking in Manhattan last August. Earlier on Thursday, a federal appeals court ruled that he was improperly ordered released by a Federal District Court judge last year. Academic groups have raised alarms over the government’s efforts to deport him.

item.title: Las universidades chinas suben en las clasificaciones mundiales; las de EE. UU. retroceden
item.description: Harvard sigue dominando, aunque ha caído al puesto 3 en una lista que mide el rendimiento académico. Otras universidades estadounidenses se rezagan con respecto a sus homólogas mundiales.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault

media:content.media:credit: Qilai Shen para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: La Universidad de Zhejiang, en Hangzhou, China, encabeza ahora una clasificación mundial de la producción investigadora, desbancando a la Universidad de Harvard.

item.title: Trump Threatened to Send the Military to Minneapolis
item.description: Also, Israel and Arab countries asked the U.S. not to attack Iran. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents in a cloud of tear gas outside the Whipple Federal Building in Minneapolis today.

item.title: Romeo Santos Reminisces About His Drake Shoutout
item.description: Romeo Santos sat down on the “Popcast” couch and recalled when Drake referenced Aventura on “The Motto” and the collaboration that followed.
item.dc:creator: Popcast

item.title: New York Sues Former C.E.O. of Covid Vaccine Maker Over Insider Trading
item.description: Robert G. Kramer sold nearly 90,000 shares of his stock in Emergent BioSolutions, knowing that large quantities of vaccine materials were contaminated, the lawsuit said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Chris Hamby

media:content.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Robert G. Kramer, former chief of Emergent BioSolutions, appearing before a House subcommittee by video in 2021.

item.title: N.S.A. Nominee Promises to Protect Elections From Foreign Interference
item.description: President Trump fired the National Security Agency’s chief back in April and has weakened cyberattack protections.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Lt. Gen. Francis L. Donovan, left, and Lt. Gen. Joshua M. Rudd testified in front of the Senate Armed Services Committee on Capitol Hill on Thursday.

item.title: Herby Pork Laab With Chile
item.description: In this take on the classic Thai dish laab (also spelled larb) moo, ground pork is pan-cooked, then stirred together with a combination of funky fish sauce, fresh and dried chiles, shallots, lime juice and an abundance of fresh herbs for brightness.

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Testani for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: How Activists in Iran Are Using Starlink to Stay Online
item.description: Activists spent years preparing for a communications blackout in Iran, smuggling in Starlink satellite internet systems and making digital shutdowns harder for the authorities to enforce.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: Middle East Images/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A Starlink receiver atop a house in Kurdistan, Iran, in 2023. About 50,000 Starlink terminals are now in the country, according to digital activists.

item.title: Kathleen Kennedy, Lucasfilm President and ‘Star Wars’ Boss, Steps Down
item.description: Kathleen Kennedy stepped down as Lucasfilm’s president and returned to producing. Two studio veterans took over.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes

media:content.media:credit: Hiro Komae/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Kathleen Kennedy and Dave Filoni at a “Star Wars” fan convention in Japan in April.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Invoke the Insurrection Act and Send Troops to Minnesota
item.description: The law, which was last invoked in 1992, could allow President Trump to deploy the military inside the United States. Doing so would be a major escalation.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Donald J. Trump in the Oval Office on Wednesday.
